sub_topic: Finding the chromatic polynomial of a graph.
message_1: What is the chromatic polynomial of a graph G, where G is the complete graph with 7 vertices?
message_2:
The chromatic polynomial of a graph G, denoted as P(G, k), is a polynomial that counts the number of proper k-colorings of the graph G. A proper k-coloring is an assignment of k colors to the vertices of the graph such that no two adjacent vertices share the same color.

For a complete graph with n vertices, denoted as K_n, the chromatic polynomial can be determined using the following formula:

P(K_n, k) = k(k-1)^{n-1}

In this case, we have a complete graph with 7 vertices, so n = 7. Plugging this into the formula, we get:

P(K_7, k) = k(k-1)^{7-1}
P(K_7, k) = k(k-1)^6

So, the chromatic polynomial of a complete graph with 7 vertices is P(K_7, k) = k(k-1)^6.
